Contradict fact: The claim that the year 2018 will see the first Christmas full moon since 1977 contradicts the fact that the full moon of December 2018 actually occurred on the 22nd day of that month, not Christmas Day (the 25th).
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is based on a meme shared on social media, which is outdated and not accurate for the year 2018.
Exist alternative explanation: The alternative explanation is that the claim was once true but was outdated in reference to the year 2018. The last Christmas full moon occurred in 1977, and the next one won't be until 2034.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times as it relies on outdated information and does not accurately represent the occurrence of a Christmas full moon in 2018.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that there will be a Christmas full moon in 2018 based on past occurrences in 1977, without considering the actual lunar calendar for that year.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the occurrence of a Christmas full moon in 2018 by stating it as a fact, even though it is not accurate.
Understate: There is no evidence of understating biases in the provided claim.
